Joining @MSNBC’s @AlexWitt in a few minutes to discuss the humanitarian crisis at the southern border. Tune in!

In a win for repro rights, SCOTUS announced that it won’t review a lower court’s decision to block Alabama’s abortion ban. This law was an egregious attack on women’s rights, and today’s decision should send a clear message to other states that similar bans will not be tolerated.

The Senate’s bill, on the other hand, does nothing to protect these children. 

Congress has a responsibility to protect these kids, and if that requires us to stay in town to hash this out and get it right, then that’s what we should be doing.

The bill we passed earlier in the House this week would not only provide the agencies caring for these children the resources they need, it would also set strict new standards to ensure these kids are receiving the care they deserve.

I can't support a bill that gives our agencies all the money they need to house these migrant kids, but does nothing to ensure they are properly cared for. Congress has a responsibility to protect these kids. I voted against the bill Congress passed today b/c it doesn’t do that.

Max Schill is one of the millions of Americans living with a rare disease. His tireless advocacy and determination to help others played a big role in getting #21stCenturyCures passed in 2016. The Supreme Court’s decision that it has no role in partisan gerrymandering cases is a devastating blow to our democracy. “Is this how American democracy is supposed to work?” Justice Kagan asked in her dissent.
 
No, no it's not.

This administration is failing these migrant kids. Our agencies need to be working together. The health and safety of these children should be everyone’s top priority, above all else. https://www.newsweek.com/migrant-children-held-border-facilities-past-72-hour-limit-1446207 …

We need these agencies working together, and we have to find a way to break down any barriers preventing them from doing that. The way that the Trump admin is treating these migrant children is unacceptable. We just passed a $4.5 billion emergency bill to deal with the crisis that the president’s shameful policy has created. This bill sets strict new standards for how these kids are to be treated.
